subject: Re: [junit] Priority of Assertion?
msgSnippet: Or: new int[0][0] throws ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException hmmm... exception(classOf[ArrayIndexoutOfBoundsException]) isThrownBy {new int[0][0]} Hmmm, cheating,
messageBody:
Or:

new int[0][0] throws ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException

hmmm...

exception(classOf[ArrayIndexoutOfBoundsException]) isThrownBy {new
int[0][0]}

Hmmm, cheating, that was scala...

exception(ArrayIndexOutoBounds.class).isThrownBy(new fn0() {
public void apply() {
new int[0][0]();
}
});

Not sure of the Scala example, something similar or better should be
possible. The java version is certainly not for the faint of heart. The
addition of anonymous functions in java would sure make this particular
example more elegant...

On Mon, Jan 5, 2009 at 5:04 PM, kentb <kentb@...> wrote:

> Another way to look at this is to free ourselves from the fetters of
> Java
> syntax and semantics for a moment and imagine what we'd like to say about
> thrown exceptions, then map that back as best we can to the real
> programming
> language. I think I'd like to say something like:
>
> ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException isThrownBy new int[0][0]
>
> This is the essential information in the situation--an exception, an
> expression, and the declaration that the expression throws the exception.
> Now the game becomes how little noise do you need to add to get to
> syntactically correct Java. There is no one right answer.
>
> Cheers,
>
>
> Kent Beck

> In rMock we used the following contruct:
>
> public void testSomething() {
> <code that we don't expect to throw an exception>
> expectThatExceptionThrown(isInstanceOf(SomeException.class));
> <code that we expect to throw an exception>
> }
>
> I think that idea is what Charlies assertThrows suggestion hinted towards.
>
> While this freedom can be abused it allows to precisely pinpoint what
> should
> throw an exception. Also, you could do all kind of hamcrest checks on the
> exception instance that is not possible to do with annotations. The
> underlying implementation in the rMock-case is that
> expectThatExceptionThrows primes the framework with an expection that any
> exception is checked against before the exception is rethrown as an error
> (if the check passes the Exception is expected and not rethrown).
>
> Jusr my 5 cents :)
>
